When driving a YAGSL swerve robot, the robot is always set up with a blue alliance perspective (even if you are on the red alliance). This means that the (0,0) coordinate is on the blue side of the field, and “forward” for your robot is towards the red wall, and “backwards” is towards the blue wall. To fix this, you just need to invert your joystick inputs for your robot translation when your robot is on the red alliance. You will want to do something like this (needs to be in a periodic() function), it will set the controls once the drive station is connected to the robot so it can pull in what color alliance you are. If the color is blue, set up your drive controls as they are now. If the color is red, invert the joystick inputs for translation (rotation will stay the same). Make sure to initialize the m_hasAppliedOperatorPerspective to false.

if (!m_hasAppliedOperatorPerspective || DriverStation.isDisabled()) {
            DriverStation.getAlliance().ifPresent(allianceColor -> {
                // Put your logic here to set controls based on alliance color
               m_hasAppliedOperatorPerspective = true;
            });
        }

I have a feeling you’re trying to “fix” something that is working. When you’re behind the glass driving on the BLUE alliance, forward on the joystick should move the robot toward the RED driver station. However, when you’re on the RED alliance, forward on the joystick should move the robot toward the BLUE driver station.

Take a look at this WPILib page:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Coordinate System

Coordinate systems are used in FRC programming in several places. A few of the common places are: robot movement, joystick input, pose estimation, AprilTags, and path planning. It is important to u...

While this is correct I had added SwerveInputStream which simplifies controller to chassis control by extending a Supplier<ChassisSpeeds> which can be used to supply ChassisSpeeds to SwerveDrive.drive or SwerveDrive.driveFieldOriented. SwerveInputStream is mutable too! So you can modify the controller behavior during execution easily! Like slow buttons can be done by calling SwerveInputStream.scaleTranslation during execution and if the modified SwerveInputStream is being used it will scale its translation!

Some other relevant features of SwerveInputStream is allianceRelativeControl which flips your controller axis according to the alliance you are on.

Read more about the SwerveInputStream here!

broncbotz3481.github.io

SwerveInputStream (Yet Another Generic Swerve Library API)

declaration: package: swervelib, class: SwerveInputStream
